update.description:
This plugin will be used to verify several of the checkpoints during the finals.

It needs [this](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/pull-requests/146/orientedbox-see-issue-59/diff) ignition math pull request.

* Competitors should not interact directly with this plugin. A Gazebo transport interface was chosen over ROS in an effort to keep the internal interface well separated from the user-facing one.

* The plugin publishes messages to Gazebo topic `<namespace>/box/contains` with 0 or 1, depending on whether the robot is currently within the given box or not.

```
data: 0
```

* The plugin can be toggled on or off through topic `<namespace>/box/toggle`. Another plugin will be doing the toggling during the competition. For now, feel free to use [this](https://bitbucket.org/snippets/chapulina/kBa86) publisher program for testing.

* Plugin parameters:

    - frequency: Publish frequency in Hz
    - entity: Scoped entity name, using "valkyrie" to check the model origin
    - namespace: Namespace for topics, there will be several of these plugins in the world, for now I'm using namespaces such as `taskN/checkpointN`
    - pose: Box pose in the world frame
    - size: Box size

* Also added an almost duplicate of `unique_task1.world` (with the added plugin) from pull request #26 for testing

* Also added launch file `unique_task1.launch`

### Try it out

1. `roslaunch srcsim unique_task1.launch init:=true`

1. Wait for Val to be lowered by the harness

1. Use the example publisher to toggle the box on: `./publisher`

1. `gz topic -e /task1/checkpoint3/box/contains` to see the 0/1 messages

1. With the translate tool, drag Val into and out of the finish box and observe the publish messages change.
update.title: Box plugin

content.raw: @nkoenig and @mikaelarguedas , I see you two have been looking at this PR. I'll merge it with one approval now so it can be integrated with pull request #30, but feel free to leave comments if you're still reviewing and I can address them in future PRs.
content.html: @nkoenig and @mikaelarguedas , I see you two have been looking at this PR. I'll merge it with one approval now so it can be integrated with pull request #30, but feel free to leave comments if you're still reviewing and I can address them in future PRs.

content.raw: Done and removed all the frequency logic: 1def157
content.html: Done and removed all the frequency logic: 1def157
Yeah sounds good, done 1def157

update.title: Box plugin

content.raw: Changing the architecture would entail moving this logic to the FinalsPlugin itself. It shouldn't be too much work.
content.html: Changing the architecture would entail moving this logic to the FinalsPlugin itself. It shouldn't be too much work.

content.raw:
Sure, we can check every cycle, but only broadcast from time to time. The thing is that the Finals plugin is relying on these messages, so that plugin will receive the information with a bit of delay and the completion time will also have some delay. 

We could try changing the architecture a bit, or just publish this at 1000Hz. What do you think is best?
content.html:
Sure, we can check every cycle, but only broadcast from time to time. The thing is that the Finals plugin is relying on these messages, so that plugin will receive the information with a bit of delay and the completion time will also have some delay.

We could try changing the architecture a bit, or just publish this at 1000Hz. What do you think is best?

content.raw:
If we want to be 100% accurate then the check for completion should happen every cycle. 

Could we apply this frequency to just the message output?
content.html:
If we want to be 100% accurate then the check for completion should happen every cycle.

Could we apply this frequency to just the message output?

content.raw: Ah good point, I chose that to reduce spamming while debugging, we can use 1000Hz to be more accurate.
content.html: Ah good point, I chose that to reduce spamming while debugging, we can use 1000Hz to be more accurate.

content.raw: No problem, stick with gazebo transport.

I suppose ign-transport2 + gazebo messages would still be an option. 

The downsides are that ign-transport2 lacks some of the features which would be convenient here, such as services with no requests, and some command line tools which help debugging.
content.html:
I suppose ign-transport2 + gazebo messages would still be an option.

The downsides are that ign-transport2 lacks some of the features which would be convenient here, such as services with no requests, and some command line tools which help debugging.

content.raw: Should we check the box at 100Hz? Is that number picked so that we get accurate completion times?
content.html: Should we check the box at 100Hz? Is that number picked so that we get accurate completion times?

content.raw: Take a look at pull request #27. Things were quickly turning into a dependency nightmare, so I "downgraded" to gazebo transport. I still plan on porting this to Gazebo 8 using ignition math 3 and ignition transport 3.
content.html: Take a look at pull request #27. Things were quickly turning into a dependency nightmare, so I "downgraded" to gazebo transport. I still plan on porting this to Gazebo 8 using ignition math 3 and ignition transport 3.

content.raw: Can we use ign-transport instead of gazebo's transport?
content.html: Can we use ign-transport instead of gazebo's transport?
